articleTitle: Electronic arms and legs: Meeting the bionic challenge: Though still far from creating a six-million-dollar man, the progress of electronic prosthesis technology is nothing short of a biotechnical wonder
The computer revolution in medical imaging systems: Computers have become an essential part of medical imaging, where their many uses include control of hardware and image enhancement and generation
Instrumentation for analyzing biological cells: Research efforts are focused on the complementary use of instruments that measure and sort potential cancer cells and those that yield photometric data
Looking back [Man of High Fidelity: Edwin Howard Armstrong]

On becoming an engineer part I: The impulse function: The first of three articles examines the transition from the classroom to your first job. How should you approach it? Hit it hard with all you have

Job prospects '84: Optimistic, but not dramatic: Employers are optimistic about the class of '84, but caution that you should expect fewer offers and slight salary increases — And be willing to relocate
The EE and health care policy: A call to action: Lack of engineering involvement has led to government policies that have cast the profession in a poor light. The time is ripe for concerted action
Unification through registration: Unification of the profession through registration will help clear the confusion about what constitutes the practice of engineering

Computer science and engineering: Laying claim to a new discipline: If engineering is to lay claim to the new computer field, it needs to widen its perspective and regard the computer as more than a tool
View from the top: Planning a successful enterprise: Most business failures are not due to product or service shortfall, but to lack of planning and financial and marketing savvy
The hills are alive … with the synthesis of music: Digital synthesizers are outpacing their older analog counterparts, particularly in the area of commercial music
The rise of the writing class: The need for written communication skills has given rise to an effort to give EEs better training as students or to send them back to school on the job
How leaders become managers: Natural leaders, with training, evolve into professional managers. This transition is the greatest challenge to career development
EE at work: Communication — It's not just talk: Getting the word around — Quickly and accurately — Had led to a burgeoning field for EEs who can design systems that are fast and flexible
Local area networks: Local area networks — An interconnection of computers and peripherals in adjacent rooms or buildings — Can provide cost-effective communications
The great oral examination face-off! Psychological warfare at its best: The examiner's goal is to rattle the student, while the victim coolly counterattacks. Both should wear dark glasses

EE at work: For a bioengineer, the checkered path to administration: He started out with a biology degree. Several years of training and experience later, this bioengineer helps set policy for the Veterans Administration
Clinical engineering: An education with a future: The degree to which clinical engineering will be successful depends on the type of educational program its future practitioners select
Ham radio operation: A not-so-amateur pastime: From computer applications to space technology, amateur radio presents a unique opportunity for technical innovation and experimentation
The art of effective persuasion: Understanding other people's behavioral patterns can often help you communicate and persuade more effectively
A bright future for fiber optic communications: New developments in fiber optic technology are transforming lightwave communications into one of the fastest growing areas of electronics
Transforming the image of the engineer: The challenge to engineers is to change their image by making their presence felt in in civic, governmental, and professional affairs
Jobs across the sea: Working abroad offers professional, personal, and financial rewards but demands maximum flexibility and several years' experience on home turf
EE at work: The precise science of instrumentation: The EE who goes into instrumentation design must be prepared to deal with very demanding requirements and be a perfectionist at heart
Are SPACs effective? SPACs can be effective in increasing professional awareness and interest in branch activities, but branch officers have to maintain the momentum
Engineer or technologist: A matter of degree? Part III: The quality of EET programs varies widely. Adherence to uniform standards will help to clarify career options and opportunities
Surviving the firing line: As the shakeout in the computer industry intensifies, many EEs are unexpectedly losing their jobs. Be prepared, in case you're caught in the line of fire
View from the top: The race for high-tech supremacy: In order to maintain market superiority, high-tech industries must increase R&D efforts; government, academia, and industry need to join forces
On the job with three co-ops: Co-op programs give students a chance to try out the “real thing” before graduation. The experience sometimes leads to surprising discoveries
A look at computer networks through a system of layers: The design of computer networks is explained through an example that employs the ISO/ANSI reference model
EE at work: On the fast track with the Navy: The government worker's image may be a little tarnished, but working for the Navy has given this EE unmatched responsibility and advancement

View from the top: At Intel, decision-making without walls: Effective decision-making, says the president of Intel, means striking a balance between the forces of knowledge and the power of experience
New horizons for communications satellites: New technology is directed at alleviating interference and congestion by using higher frequencies and achieving greater capacity per orbital slot
From Maxwell to Marconi: The genesis and birth of radio: A 30-year span saw the evolution of radio communications from an experimental novelty to an international commodity
The IEEE McNaughton learning resource centers: One student branch's initiative provided the impetus for the chain of McNaughton Learning Centers that have sprung up around Canada
T-shirt contest winner and other favorites
New roles for EEs as volunteers

10 Centennial students make IEEE history: They came from all Regions of the IEEE; they mingled with the giants of the past and the greats of the present, and they left feeling a little taller themselves
MIT students meet PAC-THING: The lesson in this annual engineering contest is not in if you win or lose, but in how well you design

View from the top: Communications: Some futurethink about a leading technology: The author predicts greater communications capability, with fibers leading the way, and hopes we will continue to escape the Orwellian prediction
Time-tested methods for effective time management: Regardless of what you think time is, these techniques will make your personal and professional life more productive
Dr. Coleman is number one Branch Counselor: A lot of talent and hard work go into guiding student activities. UNCC's Dr. Coleman obviously has the right stuff
Crosstalk: Humanities courses? A resounding yes
Across the Atlantic: Networks of friendship: Region 8 has been immensely successful in building networks of friendship that transcend national, cultural, religious, and educational boundaries
C. Richard Johnson Jr.: An outstanding young EE: Do electrical engineering, academia, and international interests make a winning combo? Ask the winner of two coveted Eta Kappa Nu awards

Reading up books: Bioengineering: A beginner's bibliography: A good bioengineer must have a solid background in engineering principles and then in biological applications. Here are some books to get you started

Reading up books: A review of circuit analysis texts: Text selection for circuit analysis classes can be difficult. The emergence of texts that can be used by students as learning aids may provide one answer
A controller-recorder for the Get Away Special: This award-winning student paper describes a microprocessor-based controller that will monitor experiments in the space shuttle's GAS container

Reading up books: Readings in communications: A historical review: A good approach for a student interested in communications is to trace its historical development through the literature of the times
1984 Outstanding branch counselors/advisors: This award recognizes those counselors and advisors who truly motivate their students to higher levels of technical and professional competence
Reading up books: Computer-aided circuit analysis and design: A discussion of the role of the digital computer in circuit analysis and design is followed by a review of current literature
